job_title: Certified Flight Instructor in Romeoville, IL
pros: Aircraft are very well maintained. You will build lots of time as a full-time instructor. Other coworkers are very great to work with.
cons: Pay and schedule can be much better. Full time employees work 6 days a week (monday-saturday) and shifts can be 10 hours or more if the weather is good. Pay is only $30k a year. Considering our long work weeks and hours, the pay should be much better.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Saint Charles, IL
pros: The University provides you through its Department (Department Head), Dean and Office of the President the resources to excel at teaching. The university allows and trusts you with tailoring your own classes to how you want to teach.
cons: Many of the institutional regulations and the navigation to promotion you have to figure out yourself. Also for those professors who are research focused, the University does not provide much time for that because of the 4,4 teaching load.

pros: Can't think of anything really
cons: Any and everything but especially professionalism of management

pros: The tuition benefit is excellent. Your entire family can get their college degrees. The vacation time is good as well along with many holidays and an extended break over Christmas and New Years.
cons: Salaries are low (unless you are senior management or a professor) and there is not really a way for a real raise as increases are across the board approved by the board and are 2% so whether you are an outstanding employee or dead weight you will get the same raise. Senior management is out of touch with reality when hiring new employees and relies to much on the tuition benefit to significantly undercut starting pay.

review_title: Proud to be part of a positively contributing group a clinicians & academicians
pros: Strong, committed group of peers and support staff, all willing to constantly grow and improve our work. Former students have continued to achieve Advance Practice Nurse Board Certification and Doctorates.
cons: Most things change too slowly to give the University the competitive edge it says it wants. Often the various colleges are operating on their own agenda and collaboration can be spotty.

pros: Benefits include a flexible work schedule during the summer, tuition waiver, decent insurance coverage.  Overall not that demanding work.
cons: Management does not give any insight whatsoever as to long-term career opportunities and how to improve oneself; management is hesitant to provide professional development opportunities.  There absolutely no clear-cut definition or process of how to receive a salary increase.  Shared work-space makes for uncomfortable working conditions.

review_title: Student worker in office of technology
job_title: Laboratory Assistant and Researcher in Crest Hill, IL
pros: Lewis home  away from home .As a student i was able to work hand in hand with the professors and got so many projects done. I learnt a lot in  both the technology and the finance field. The professors were very helpful and my boss was willing to help me learn more whenever i needed to
cons: The only constraint was that it was  a bit hard for me to balance up my books since i was doing a masters program with my work schedule

review_title: Loved coming to work everyday, hated the feeling of being stuck and undervalued
pros: The university holds their mission statement very close in everything they do. This true for decisions made at every level and the interviewing process. This is a good and welcoming approach and is likely one of the reasons they're such a great university. Everyone is very friendly, including the students. I felt like I was a part of a family there. They also like to feed employees and staff with periodic events to show appreciation or support various groups or causes.
cons:
Don't expect any raises or career growth. The university sticks to a 1-2% raise every year for every employee universally. Anything beyond that is extremely rare. There is also very little hierarchy in staff positions, so moving up the career ladder is not possible either. While the university loves to employ their own graduates or move staff into other positions when openings do occur, I've seen most of the upper-;level positions become filled with outsiders. There is nothing wrong with that and most of these positions need the right person for the job. However, the impression is that little value or consideration is given to existing candidates.

Also, the politics involved in day-to-day work are tedious. Some people hold themselves too high to be considerate or allow for the job to be done as best as it could be, faculty tend to procrastinate as badly as their students, and committees seem to exist for the sake of having committees.

pros: Working at Lewis as a Graduate Assistant opened so many opportunities for me from working along side professionals, offering hands on learning, service opportunities, professional development, and most of all helping pay for my Master program which I would have never been able to do on my own. Lewis is a great place.
cons: Overall I think any cons I experienced are outweighed by the positive impact my time at Lewis had on my personal and professional life.

cons: During busy times, space may be a problem and noise might inhibit the ability to tutor.  Maximum amount of hours allowed is sometimes a negative, but I understand that they prioritize schoolwork first.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Tinley Park, IL
pros: Lewis University is excellent in both undergraduate and graduate programs. They provide a rich history and valuable education while true to their mission and vision.
cons: There are no criticisms that apply to a review of Lewis University. The university is outstanding in academics and programs.

job_title: Orientation Group Leader in Romeoville, IL
pros: Great people to work with. It's a friendly community of hardworking honest people. They have a strong mission statement and the employee's hold true to it.
cons: It is a small community so things travel around the community quickly. There is some bureaucratic processes that take time to get through.

pros: My boss is extremely flexible and I work with some really mature, professional people. Lewis has the feel of an old place with old traditions. But the leadership is making a good effort to stay modern.
cons: Just like any other religious institution, there is a lot of politics and favoritism. But if you can work your way around that, you'll do just fine.

review_title: The organization is mission driven and the faculty and staff are committed to the success of every student.
pros: The organization thrives as a positive environment where one enjoys working and collaborating with colleagues who genuinely care for one another.
cons: There are minimal opportunities for professional development and many times the opportunities that are offered are not relevant to the professional growth of the employee.

pros: The benefits are significant. There is a great pension contribution provided by the employer. The free soup and salad for lunch is also a great benefit.
cons: There really aren't too many challenges due to the benefits. Some departments have directors or higher that have been employed for a long time which may leave little room for movement in this setting.

review_title: Great people, but low pay and bad chain of command.
pros: Nice people. Some people in certain offices are very friendly and encouraging. Beautiful campus and flexibility with working over 30 hours.
cons: Preferential treatment. Low pay. No room for advancement. High turnover due to management in administrative departments and low employee morale. Processes and office equipment needs updating.
